pullRequest.body:
Writing `change? (some term)` tries to unify the given term with the current goal and prints the result of unification (and instantiation of meta-variables).  This is useful to replace a `dsimp` by a `change ...`, when you already know what you would like the end defeq expression to look like.

[Zulip discussion](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/270676-lean4/topic/Copying.20from.20the.20widget.20view)

---

nodes.body: @thorimur thank you very much for your suggestions: the new code looks so much better!
LGTM! :) Thanks for being so responsive! At some point we will also want to add `at` syntax as well, but this is a very nice PR as-is. Thanks for writing it! :)
Yes, `at`-syntax is next!  It would be nice if there were a tactic for converting a tactic to `at`-syntax... üôÉ

@adomani, the repo now contains files "test/Change.lean" and "test/change.lean". One overwrites the other when the repo is checked out on a case-insensitive filesystem.
This should obviously generate a `try this` / code action intead of logging!

I figured out how to do it!

Although, maybe this tactic is obsolete, given the discussion in the corresponding Zulip thread.

```suggestion
  let expr ‚Üê match sop with
    | none => getMainTarget
    | some ex => do
      let ex ‚Üê elabTerm ex none
      let defeq? ‚Üê isDefEq ex (‚Üê getMainTarget)
      if ! defeq? then throwError "The given term is not DefEq to the goal"
      instantiateMVars ex
  let dstx ‚Üê delabToRefinableSyntax expr
```
Is this just a stylistic change, or is there a difference to omitting the `:=`?
It's purely stylistic. :) At least, I believe so...!

```suggestion
      let ex ‚Üê elabTermEnsuringType ex (‚Üê inferType <|‚Üê getMainTarget)
```
Should we elaborate `ex` while ensuring the type of the main goal (instead of `none`), since we know it has to be defeq to the main goal? (There might be an unexpected reason not to, I'm not completely sure.)
This seems like a good idea to me, but then I'd move the error about non-defeq to this step, right?  (I'll do it myself, but I won't get around to it for today.)
By the way, I wonder if this change would fix what I consider a bug: with the running `fun` example, using `change? _ = 1` seems to ignore the hint and returns `fun ...`.
I think It might actually be more informative to let `elabTermEnsuringType` report its own error! Then the user knows that the problem is specifically a type mismatch, not a term-level defeq problem.
Ok, in any case, the explicit defeq test and the error then should be removed entirely, right?
Hmm, I don't think so, if I understand correctly‚Äîwe *do* still want to test that `ex` is defeq to the main target. `elabTermEnsuringType` just checks that these expressions have the same type.

Also, if you do opt to click commit suggestion on the larger `elab_rules` suggestion, I'll update my suggestion here, as we should use `withRef` to report the type error on the term syntax specifically: e.g. `withRef sop <| elabTermEnsuringType ...`. Or if you'd like to make changes manually from your local repo, I'd recommend including `withRef` as appropriate (whatever's more convenient). :)

I committed your elab_rules suggestion.  I plan to commit all the remaining as well.  I got into the habit of doing it while I am in front of a computer, to catch errors right away, but I'm happy to make exceptions!

````suggestion
/-- `change? term` unifies `term` with the current goal, then suggests explicit `change` syntax
that uses the resulting unified term.

If `term` is not present, `change?` suggests the current goal itself. This is useful after tactics 
which transform the goal while maintaining definitional equality, such as `dsimp`; those preceding 
tactic calls can then be deleted.
```lean
example : (fun x : Nat => x) 0 = 1 := by
  change? 0 = _  -- `Try this: change 0 = 1`
```
-/
````

```suggestion
# Tactic `change? term`

This tactic is used to suggest a replacement of the goal by a definitionally equal term.
`term` is intended to contain holes which get unified with the main goal and filled in explicitly 
in the suggestion.

`term` can also be omitted, in which case `change?` simply suggests `change` with the main goal. 
This is helpful after tactics like `dsimp`, which can then be deleted.
```

For ease of maintenance by others, this should probably use `elab_rules` syntax instead of low-level syntax manipulation. Three other misc. changes:
1. It seems to be standard to put the blue squiggle under the initial token instead of the whole thing; we pass `origSpan?` to tell `addSuggestion` to replace the whole thing upon clicking, though. :)
2. I added `throwErrorAt` to report the defeq error on `sop`; this means that we match against `some sop` instead of `some ex`.
3. I added `withMainContext`.
```suggestion
elab_rules : tactic
| `(tactic|change?%$tk $[$sop:term]?) => withMainContext do
  let stx ‚Üê getRef
  let expr ‚Üê match sop with
    | none => getMainTarget
    | some sop => do
      let ex ‚Üê elabTerm sop none
      let defeq? ‚Üê isDefEq ex (‚Üê getMainTarget)
      if ! defeq? then throwErrorAt sop "The given term is not DefEq to the goal"
      instantiateMVars ex
  let dstx ‚Üê delabToRefinableSyntax expr
  addSuggestion tk (‚Üê `(tactic| change $dstx)) (origSpan? := stx)
```
I didn't know about `getRef`, which is why I had used the weird definition.  It was my hacky way of getting my hands on the whole syntax.
Ah, gotcha‚ÄîI thought that might have been why. It took a second for me to locate it as well.

(Since we'd be using `getMainTarget` twice if using `elabTermEnsuringType`, I factored it out.)
```suggestion
      let tgt ‚Üê getMainTarget
      let ex ‚Üê withRef sop <| elabTermEnsuringType sop (‚Üê inferType tgt)
      let defeq? ‚Üê isDefEq ex tgt
```

Ah, I was confused before about the defeq test, since I was thinking "these are all Props", but of course the defeq test is on the term, while the elabTerm is using `inferType`!  I'm normally slow, even in front of a computer, but on mobile, I cannot even test things out!  üôÉ

The tests work fine for me without this.
```suggestion
```

I thought that this was useful since otherwise the `fun` arrow gives incompatible errors for `guard_msgs`.  Am I wrong?

I was in this situation, where either the error was on my local machine or on CI until Kyle mentioned this option.

Oh, maybe CI works differently? I can confirm that locally the `fun` arrows print as `‚Ü¶` for me (and `#guard_msgs` sees them that way too). I suppose it doesn't hurt to ensure that this option is `true`. :)
If you are curious, try looking at the tests for ExtractGoal: I had to use it there and there I tested it.  Here I just placed it based on memory.

https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/4595#issuecomment-1662171855
and below.
Ah, I see! Thanks for the reference!

Last thing I can think of, then this LGTM: this error message should probably be more informative:
```suggestion
      if ! defeq? then throwErrorAt sop "The term{indentD ex}\nis not defeq to the goal:{
        indentD tgt}"
```
By using `ex` instead of `sop`, we can give the user a clue as to what went wrong.

The next comment adjusts the tests appropriately.

Note: we don't use `_` because it becomes `?m.96`, and that's quite fragile to put in a `#guard_msgs`
```suggestion
error: The term
  1 = 0
is not defeq to the goal:
  (fun x ‚Ü¶ x) 0 = 1
-/
#guard_msgs in
example : (fun x : Nat => x) 0 = 1 := by
  change? 0 = _  -- change 0 = 1
  change?        -- change (fun x ‚Ü¶ x) 0 = 1
  change? _      -- change (fun x ‚Ü¶ x) 0 = 1
  change? 1 = 0
    -- The term
    --   1 = 0
    -- is not defeq to the goal:
    --   (fun x ‚Ü¶ x) 0 = 1
```

```suggestion
      let !(‚Üê isDefEq ex tgt) then throwErrorAt sop "The term{indentD ex}\nis not defeq to the goal:{
        indentD tgt}"
```
